Situation1: They find a broken lane rope that could disrupt swim lessons if not fixed soon.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: I was doing my usual rounds at the pool, clipboard in hand, when I spotted the broken lane rope. Swim lessons were about to start, and I knew the kids would be at risk if the lanes weren’t clearly marked. As a lifeguard, it was my job to keep the equipment in top shape, and I felt the pressure to fix it immediately. Just as I knelt to untangle the mess, the building alarms blared. Through the windows, I saw water rushing down the street—flash-flood warning. My phone buzzed with emergency alerts, urging all citizens to evacuate and help neighbors if possible. I froze, torn. As a citizen, I was expected to follow public safety orders, maybe even check on the elderly couple next door. But as a lifeguard, I couldn’t leave the pool in disarray, risking the safety of the kids about to arrive. My heart pounded as I weighed the demands, feeling the pull of both responsibilities, knowing I couldn’t fulfill them both at once.
